The Automated Malware Detection System is an advanced cybersecurity solution designed to detect and classify various types of malware using machine learning techniques. This system can analyze software behavior and code patterns in real-time, enabling quick identification of potential threats before they infiltrate a network or system. Upon detecting malware, the system immediately alerts the user and isolates the threat, ensuring minimal damage and preventing further spread. Key features include the ability to learn and adapt to new malware signatures, continuously updating its detection algorithms to stay ahead of emerging threats. highlighttitle: An IoT-powered smart sorting machine that classifies objects by color and magnetic properties while logging real-time data for remote monitoring and analytics.
prodinfo:
Objective

The objective of this project is to design and develop a smart, automated object sorting system that categorizes items based on their color and magnetic properties using advanced sensing technology. The system integrates IoT connectivity to log real-time sorting data onto a cloud platform like ThingSpeak, enabling remote monitoring and analysis through a custom mobile application. This project aims to reduce human effort, minimize sorting errors, and increase efficiency in industries dealing with mixed objects such as recycling plants, manufacturing units, and warehouses. Additionally, the collected data helps in understanding sorting trends and operational efficiency, providing actionable insights to the user from any location via a user-friendly dashboard.

One-Liner Description

An IoT-powered smart sorting machine that classifies objects by color and magnetic properties while logging real-time data for remote monitoring and analytics.

Abstract

The IoT-Enabled Smart Object Sorting Machine is designed to automate the sorting of objects based on color and magnetic characteristics. Using a microcontroller (ESP32) as the brain, the system integrates a color sensor, a Hall-effect sensor, a servo motor for gate control, and a motor driver for conveyor belt operations. Sorted data is logged into the ThingSpeak cloud platform, where it is visualized and analyzed. The owner can access live sorting data, reports, and analytics through a custom mobile application. Notifications such as buzzer alerts and LED indicators enhance real-time feedback during operation. This system reduces manual labor, improves sorting accuracy, and enhances productivity in industries where sorting is crucial. Its integration with IoT provides valuable data for decision-making and remote supervision, making it a cost-effective and modern solution for automated object classification.

Information

This project uses an ESP32 microcontroller as the central unit, connected to a color sensor (TCS3200) for detecting object color and a Hall-effect sensor for identifying magnetic materials. The objects are transported on a DC motor-driven conveyor belt controlled via an L298N motor driver. Based on classification, servo motors operate sorting gates that direct items into respective bins. A 0.96" OLED display provides on-device feedback, while LED indicators and a buzzer give real-time operation status. The ESP32 uploads data to the ThingSpeak cloud, where parameters such as counts of different object categories are stored and visualized. The custom mobile app allows owners to monitor data, receive notifications, and analyze sorting trends from anywhere. This makes the system highly adaptable for industries like recycling, waste management, and manufacturing.

Key Features

  • IoT-enabled data logging with ThingSpeak cloud integration
  • Dual sorting mechanism: Color-based and magnetic detection

  • Servo-controlled gates for accurate object separation
  • Buzzer and LED alerts for system status notifications
  • Motor-driven conveyor belt for continuous operation
  • Data visualization dashboards for analytics

  • Low-cost, modular, and scalable design

IoT, ESP32, ThingSpeak, Smart Sorting, Color Sensor, Magnetic Detection, Conveyor Belt, Servo Motor, Data Logging, Remote Monitoring, Industrial Automation

Applications

  • E-waste management to separate metallic and non-metallic components
  • Logistics and warehouses for automatic sorting of packaged goods
  • Educational projects for IoT, automation, and robotics research

Advantages

Limitations

  • Not suitable for sorting very large or irregularly shaped objects

Future Scope

  • Adding weight sensors for multi-parameter sorting

Conclusion

The IoT-Enabled Smart Object Sorting Machine is an innovative solution designed to bring automation, accuracy, and intelligence into the sorting process. By utilizing a combination of color sensors, Hall-effect sensors, servo motors, and IoT connectivity, the system ensures efficient classification of objects while providing real-time monitoring and data analytics through the ThingSpeak platform and a custom mobile app. While it currently sorts based on color and magnetic properties, its design is modular, enabling easy upgrades for future features such as weight and shape detection. This project not only reduces manual labor but also offers valuable insights into sorting trends, making it highly suitable for industries ranging from recycling to manufacturing. With continuous improvements and scalability, the system can play a significant role in advancing smart automation in industrial and environmental applications.

Abstract

This mini project presents an Arduino Nano-controlled collision-avoidance vehicle that uses an ultrasonic sensor to perceive obstacles and autonomously mitigate crash risk. The sensor samples distance ahead, filtered through a moving-average or median approach to reduce noise, and feeds a finite state machine with three modes: Cruise, Caution, and Stop. In Cruise, motors run at a set PWM duty; in Caution, speed is reduced and alerts are issued; in Stop, the vehicle brakes and holds until the path is clear. A standard H-bridge driver controls the DC motors, while a compact Li-ion battery pack powers logic and actuators through a regulated rail. The design focuses on simplicity, low part count, and easy calibration of safe-distance thresholds. Optional features include a servo-mounted sensor for basic scanning and an audible indicator for user feedback. The result is a practical demonstration of autonomous safety behavior in a small, low-speed platform.

Keywords

Ultrasonic sensor, Arduino Nano, Collision avoidance, Autonomous vehicle, State machine, Embedded system, PWM control, H-bridge, Obstacle detection, Educational robotics

Project Information

Hardware: Arduino Nano (or compatible), HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor, L298N/L9110S motor driver, two DC gear motors with wheels, caster wheel, mini chassis, Li-ion battery pack with protection (BMS) and 5V regulator, switch, LEDs/buzzer, and basic wiring components. Software: Arduino IDE with simple state-machine logic. The ultrasonic module measures time-of-flight to compute distance; readings are debounced and filtered. A configurable safeDistance (e.g., 2540 cm) governs transitions: above threshold Cruise; near threshold Caution (slow); below threshold Stop. Abstract

This mini project implements a low-cost one-axis solar tracker that automatically orients a small solar panel toward the sun to maximize energy capture. The system uses multiple light-dependent resistors (LDRs) arranged around the panel to sense directional irradiance differences. An Arduino Nano reads the LDR voltages, computes the error between left and right illumination, and drives a hobby servo motor to rotate the panel on a single axis until illumination is balanced or within a defined threshold. Visual indicators (LEDs) and an optional buzzer provide simple status feedback and alerts for calibration or faults. The mechanical structure is deliberately lightweight and easy to build from cardboard or low-cost materials to keep the project accessible for classroom demonstrations and rapid prototyping. The tracker increases effective incident sunlight on the panel compared to a fixed mount, demonstrating improved charging or output for small loads such as phone charging or powering low-power sensors. Project Information

The one-axis solar tracker is a compact electromechanical system designed to orient a small photovoltaic panel toward the sun throughout the day. The sensing subsystem comprises two or four LDRs placed around the panel to detect relative light intensity; the controller subsystem is an Arduino Nano that samples analog readings, filters noise with simple averaging, and runs a proportional control routine to adjust the servo position. The actuator is a standard 180 hobby servo that rotates the panel about a single axis (tilt or azimuth depending on mounting). A basic user interface uses LEDs to indicate tracking, idle, or error states, and a buzzer for fault signals. The mechanical frame is intentionally simple cardboard or thin plywood enabling fast assembly and low cost. Power for the controller can come from the small panel itself (with regulation) or an external 5V supply for consistent testing. The system includes calibration steps to set neutral position and sensitivity thresholds so it avoids oscillation in low-contrast lighting. Data logging is optional using serial output for demonstration of improved voltage/current when tracking versus fixed orientation. Overall, the project is intended as an educational demonstration with measurable gains in small-scale solar harvesting and clear paths for expansion.

Project Objective

The objective is to design, build, and demonstrate a simple, reliable one-axis solar tracking prototype using low-cost, readily available components. Specifically, the project aims to show how automatic alignment increases the effective solar input on a small panel compared to a static mount. The tracker should operate autonomously: sensing sunlight distribution with LDRs, processing signals on an Arduino Nano, and actuating a servo to reduce the light imbalance. It must include basic user feedback (LEDs/buzzer) and simple calibration to tune sensitivity and travel limits. Emphasis is placed on accessibility the mechanical frame and electronics should be easy to assemble by students or hobbyists with minimal tools. The controller software should be robust against sensor noise and avoid motor hunting by implementing threshold hysteresis and safe movement limits. Finally, the project should produce demonstrable output: comparative voltage/current readings or a quick charging test to quantify efficiency gains, thereby educating users on practical renewable energy improvements achievable with straightforward automation.
